title: Heterogeneous Generative Dataset for UAV Intrusion Detection
subtitle: Synthetic Data Generation for Cybersecurity ML Models
description: Developed a heterogeneous synthetic dataset generation framework for training UAV intrusion detection systems, addressing data scarcity and class imbalance. Published at IEEE MOST 2023.

body.title: Research Motivation
paragraphs: Training effective intrusion detection systems for UAV networks requires massive amounts of labeled attack data, which is expensive, dangerous, and time-consuming to collect from real deployments.
Existing datasets suffer from severe class imbalance, limited attack diversity, and lack of realistic edge cases, resulting in ML models that fail to generalize to novel attack patterns.
Real-world UAV security data is often proprietary or classified, creating a critical barrier for academic research and model development.

body.title: Technical Approach
paragraphs: Designed a generative framework that synthesizes realistic, heterogeneous network traffic patterns for UAV communication, modeling both benign operations and diverse attack scenarios.
Implemented multiple data generation techniques including GANs (Generative Adversarial Networks), variational autoencoders, and statistical modeling to capture traffic distribution diversity.
Developed a parameterized attack simulation engine that generates synthetic intrusion patterns across multiple attack categories: DoS, spoofing, injection, eavesdropping, and jamming.
Engineered data augmentation pipelines with careful control of class balance, feature distributions, and statistical properties to match real-world UAV network characteristics.

body.title: Results & Impact
paragraphs: Generated a comprehensive dataset with balanced representation across attack types, enabling robust training of intrusion detection models without real-world data collection risks.
Demonstrated that models trained on synthetic data achieved comparable or superior performance to models trained on limited real-world datasets, while generalizing better to novel attacks.
Published at IEEE MOST 2023 (7th International Conference on Mobility, Sensing and Networking), contributing a reproducible methodology for synthetic security dataset generation.
Dataset generation framework adaptable to other domains requiring security training data, including IoT networks, industrial control systems, and edge computing environments.
